TABY OF THE STATE HANKING BOARD 19 * bank was placed in the hands of the receiver January 9, 1902, with total assets amounting to $51,682.36, and liabili - ties aggregating $34,438.13; the receiver paid all liabilities in full, except liabilities not proved, amounting to $418.70; paid the expenses of winding up the affairs of the bank, Kunting to $4,149.89, and had remaining in his hand amounting to $7,242.94. There has been a tendency in a few instances for bank chartered as commercial banks to receive savings depot also a few cases where banks chartered as savings bank rated to do a commercial business. In either instance wherever found, the department has enforced the law an< compelled commercial banks to refrain from doing a sav inn bank business, and savings banks from doing a com mercial luisi' The Department is pleased to report that the banks un der state supervision, as a rule, comply with the provisioi of the Banking Act, giving the Department but little troi tbut some practices arc indulged in which, in my opinioi not only irregular, but unsound. There is a tendency < the part of some banks, when demand for loans is pressing to issue certificates of deposit for borrowed moneV in orde to avoid showing a rediscount or bills payable. The pra. tice is certainly reprehensible and prohibited. Also thei is a disposition at times to earn its of a bank varioi kinds of stocks, which is not only unsound, but unauthorize and prohibited by the Department. RECOMMENDATIONS While the Banking Act of this state in the main proven very satisfactory, experience has shown that some needed amendments are required to make it effective. I'mler the present provisions banks under the supervision of this Department are required to pay for but one examination each year. Experience proves that it is sometimec sarv to make more than one examination each year in order

20 FOURTEENTH ANNUAL REPORT OF THE tthe requirements of the law enforced. This is usually B td the negligence or incompetence of the management the bank, and I would respectfully recommend an amend - ■iit providing that an examination fee shall be paid for lamination found J by the Department. lere is no reason why, in case- where the management nore than one examination necessary, that the work ould be done for nothing. I With regard to a surplus fund, under the present revenue w a hank is taxed on its capital, surplus and undivided uh"t>. Thi.- provision of the law has a tendency to discour - ;e, on the part of banks, the building up of a surplus fund, rich is certainly i nard to the solvency of a bank, d the Department l>elieves that it would be wise to only x the capital and surplus up to the point where the sur - per cent of the capital. This would have a y to encourage the building np of a Mirplus which uld not be but beneficial. It is further recommended that the present Banking be amended so that a bank may loan l'<> per cent of its capi - .nd surplus to any one individual, firm or corporation. capital, as now provided. In for each examiner by tlie last legis - jre was $1,200.00 for the biennium, making $600.00 each ir for expenses, which includes transportation. It must evident to the law-making body that this sum is entirely dequate unl< \aminers accept free railroad ti •tation. If in the opinion of the next legislature the rail - id pass is an evil and should be abolished, the present aking Act should be amended and appropriation made ticient to cover the traveling expenses of the examiners, ich it is estimated would require an appropriation about lble the amount heretofore appropriated. My predecessor recommended that the word "bank" be denned by statute, and my experience bears him out in mak - ing the recommendation. The statute should provide that

21 the word "bank" or "banker" be used only by an indi - vidual, firm or corporation chartered to do a banking busi - j, and the word "'bank" or "banking" be specifically de - fined as doing any one or all of the following: Receiving deposit Paying check Buying and Belling exchange ■ Pursuing any one or all of the above as a business should constitute a bank or banking business and necessitate a proper authorization by the supervising authorities of the state. 22 Hon. Frank Jonvenat introduced a l)ill in the last legis lature which became a law July 1. 1905, requiring a fee of 'Hi to be paid to the state for each charter issued by the State Hanking Board. Since this law took effect there have been 4l' banks chartered op to January 1, 1906, for which the state received $1,050.00. Six hundred and sixty-three examinations were made dur- ing I!"*.") by the four state liank examiners, including build and loan associations, for which the state received in $10,92J Total expenses of Examiners, including salaries Leaving a surplus of 1, .'!.'!, .4^ Twenty-two special examinations were made during the . for which no fee could be charged under the present In conclusion. 1 beg to thank the members of the Statt Hanking Hoard for their wise counsel, courteous treatment and careful consideration of all matters brought to their at- tention. E\> the bankers of the state I desire to express my appre - tion of their co-operation in accomplishing what attended the Department, by their conservative -iness methods and prompt compliance with instructions from the Department To the Examiners and Department force I acknow I sincere gratitude for their valuable services, faithful "ormance of every duty imposed upon them, and the very ient manner in which they have disposed of the vast amount of work entrusted to their can Very Respectfully submitted E. ROYSE, Secretary State Banking Board
